direction.raw_text: An unparalleled set of sheer mountains -- part of the Colorado Rockies. The peaks rise a challenging half mile and more out of the valley -- wind-whipped snow mists over the mountains like a low fog. The tranquility is broken as a helicopter
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: into view, fighting the wind as it heads for the center of it all. Our CREDITS fly us past and through this magnificent range. There are sky-piercing peaks that slope up to a narrow, high pinnacle -- and others that are steel, straight-up approaches to large plateaus. One of the mountains has a crystal lake on top -- with a waterfall that drains from it and exits from the middle of a mountain wall. Nearby, an abandoned cable ladder is bolted into the same wall, leading to the top.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can see a man sitting in its doorway, looking out -- INT/EXT HELICOPTER - BINOCULAR POV The glasses scan systematically, slowly -- to us, it looks like nothing more than a field of gray and white.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Nothing yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The helicopter now circles this tallest mountain -- "The Tower", separated from a lower but equally formidable peak by a chasm of two hundred feet -- that drops 3,500 feet below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FRANK AND MAGGIE Spotter FRANK NEWELL (50s) scans the mountain wall.  MAGGIE DEIGHAN (30s) expertly pilots the helicopter through the storm winds. Both wear orange jackets identifying themselves as members of the Rocky Mountain Park Rescue Team.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute -- there's Hal. (beat) And his date.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: that's part of the smaller peak. HAL TUCKER (30s) and his "date", SUSAN COLLINS (20s), are decked out in climbing gear. Hal's aplomb suggests he's a veteran climber -- Susan's worried look shows she isn't. Hal and Susan huddle together, both cold, but okay. Hal has a makeshift splint wrapped around his lower leg, and a slow burning flare in one hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank lowers his glasses -- Maggie struggles with the wind.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How do they look?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hal, now aware of the copter, looks towards it, smiling -- and starts jerking off the flare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The POV dips down -- there's somebody climbing below, in an orange rescue jacket.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) He's signalling "okay."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Where's Gabe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Right where he's supposed to be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: R ON THE CLIMBER This is GABE WALKER (30s). In spite of the cold and the snow, he's fearlessly, swiftly scaling the tower without safety lines, as if he's done it a hundred times. That's because he has done it a hundred times. This is what Gabe lives for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe, almost there, finds a fingertip-width handhold at arm's length -- grabbing it, he pulls himself up on the ledge with a move that's just a little tougher than chinning yourself on a doorjamb. Winded, Gabe slumps down next to the couple, and tries to light a cigarette. The lighter only sparks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hal pulls out a box of wooden matches and lights one Bogart style, one-handed with a thumbnail, cupping a hand to shield it against the wind. Gabe bends down for it -- a familiar routine. We know in a glance they've been friends for years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE HELICOPTER dips down towards the ledge -- no way can it land there. Frank lowers a rescue wire to
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me -- I know you're my salvation, and all -- do you think you could rescue us before your smoke break?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you could tell me why I am rescuing you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Basically -- I've fallen down, and I can't get up...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into radio) Rescue One -- have located helpless climber, please prepare idiot line for transport, over --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: who precariously swings out from the ledge to grab it -- the wire is just out of reach. Hal grabs the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe finally grabs the line, secures it to a heavy piton, and hammers it into the wall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rescue One -- please remind me to tell you about the time I hauled your hero here down Mt. Huntington on my back, over -- MAGGIE (O.S.) (through radio) Hal, if I hear that story one more time, I'm making you limp down the entire three thousand feet, over --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Susan) This guy showing you a good time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: swings over across to the facing mountain -- Maggie lands the copter, in spite of the winds, on a small plateau. Frank gets out to secure the wire -- there's now a lifeline spanning the chasm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe finishes anchoring the line in the rock -- he extinguishes his cigarette in the snow, and naturally, pockets the butt. Hal, propped up against the wall, expertly rigs a seat harness around his legs -- Susan helps him get part of it around his splint, and Gabe clips it to the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With that, Hal pulls himself hand-over-hand across the sloping line -- Hal makes a point of looking down -- HAL'S POV -- THE DROP is vertigo defined. Thirty five hundred feet straight down. You could stack the World Trade Center towers on top of each other and they'd still be shorter than this mountain is high. However -- HAL lets go of the overhead line and claps his hands to his face in mock horror -- he quickly whizzes down the last thirty feet of the line, where Frank catches him and pulls him out. Hal gets out of the harness, checks every stitch of it, signals thumbs-up, and sends it back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now, remember -- keep your arms and legs within the vehicle at all times -- HAL (laughing) Fuck you --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gabe, retrieves the harness on a small attachment line, and gives Susan a reassuring smile, but she's still, sensibly, very scared. Gabe recovers the harness, rigs Susan into it, and meticulously re-checks it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan nervously laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe starts to push her out on the line, but she grabs his arm in a panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan starts to tilt her head down -- Gabe gently takes hold of her chin, turning her view up to face him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan looks at Gabe -- trying to be confident -- nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe grins and gently pushes her out. Susan tentatively pulls herself across -- then develops a rhythm, building speed -- GABE'S POV - SUSAN inching away in the harness, looking more confident now -- SUSAN'S POV - GABE signalling "OK" -- "you're doing fine" -- SUSAN - ANOTHER ANGLE thirty feet out, going fine -- INSERT -- A HARNESS CLIP holding the strap under Susan's left leg breaks -- GABE'S POV - SUSAN The harness completely unravels all at once, its strands shoot through the clips -- what was a seat has become a trap door in half a second -- as the harness shoots out from under her, Susan falls but grabs the harness strand -- HAL is helpless, and can only watch as
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ready? (sees she's afraid) Did he tell you about the time he almost made it up Everest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He said you gave him a bad oxygen mask
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if he's bored you with that bullshit, then this has to be the best part of a bad date. Right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (scared but tough) Okay --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes you can. (reassuring) You can do it. Don't look down.  The whole way across, don't look down. Look at me. Just keep looking at me -- and you'll be okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. (beat) I have always depended on the kindness of Rangers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: too scared to breathe, dangles on the remaining strand of what used to be the harness -- she sways from the wind and the jerk of her own weight, her grip loosens -- INSERT - THE TOP CLIP that is supporting all of Susan's weight is being seriously tested -- a single knot in the harness has caught there, but it clearly won't last long -- GABE moves back from the ledge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe gently pulls himself up on the line, crosses his ankles on it, and clips himself on with a three foot safety line. Gabe starts smoothly, quickly pulling himself out, but -- SUSAN is in trouble -- the bobbing of the line from Gabe's weight and the winds are making her lose her grip even more -- GABE urgently pulls himself along the line faster, trying not to shake the line. As he gets closer and closer to a terrified Susan, his eyes lock on hers -- GABE Keep looking at me. Hold on -- WIDER ANGLE Gabe is only ten feet away from -- SUSAN who stares at Gabe, petrified -- this focus is helping, but her strength is just about gone -- INSERT - THE CLIP The knot has worked itself halfway through -- it doesn't make any difference how tight she holds on to the harness, the harness itself is letting go -- ON GABE who knows it and pulls himself the rest of the way, a little faster, almost bridging the gap -- ON SUSAN staring desperately at Gabe, holding on -- INSERT - THE TOP CLIP that's keeping Susan alive surrenders the knot -- it passes through, and
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (loud, in control) Hold on. I'm coming out to get you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: falls -- GABE deliberately lets go of the main line and launches himself at Susan -- THEIR HANDS miss -- ANGLE ON BOTH Gabe's three foot safety line pulls taut, testing the limits of the line above as it yanks him back -- GABE'S POV - SUSAN is just out of reach -- her hand is still stretched out, her eyes still locked on
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: who can only look down, swaying helplessly on the wire as Susan's SCREAM starts -- ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE Frank and Maggie look down in horror, but neither look as anguished as Hal -- LONG SHOT - SUSAN falling -- falling -- falling -- looking very small against the vast mountain range -- SUSAN'S POV - FALLING from this height takes the longest nineteen seconds you can imagine -- GABE twists from his safety line, spinning helplessly -- he wants to, but can't, shut his eyes -- GABE'S POV - THE CHASM Susan is gone. Her SCREAM, cut short, echoes -- the "safety" harness spirals down after her like a carefree bird -- SMASH CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - GABE'S POV OUT WINDOW - DAY As the plane dips to land, Gabe can see a bird circling far below, over the same mountainous terrain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sweating, panting, awake. It hasn't been that long since the accident -- a year, to be exact -- but he looks older. He looks as if he's watched Susan Collins drop at least one hundred times. Gabe reels himself in as a STEWARDESS hands him a glass of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Take this. (Gabe does) Afraid of flying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Falling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gabe, with no luggage, is at the small airport's only car rental counter, doing the paperwork for a RENTAL AGENT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe turns and looks at
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Midsize?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any size, any color, any model.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long will you be needing it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flat) Just under six hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) You aren't wasting any time, are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: who is standing off to the side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe's happy to see her -- but at the same time, he isn't. She looks too good -- and she brings up quite a mixed bag of memories. Maggie carves on a smile.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I knew you'd be coming by. Today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're in that much of a hurry, why don't you ride with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Maggie pilots the copter, heading out toward the mountain range. Gabe fiddles with some of the equipment inside. Both grope for a way to start the conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe flicks it on, looks at the total absence of heat as they fly over the snow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So much for small talk. Gabe is clearly uneasy watching these mountains go by. Maggie breaks an awkward silence -- MAGGIE You could have said goodbye.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is new...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a thermal scope -- picks up body heat of lost hikers --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still find the dead ones the old fashioned way, I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes head) If I did, I'd have to listen to you tell me one more time that it wasn't my fault.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angry) Today -- especially today -- you get to hear it again. The harness clip broke.  Cold stress -- one in a million equipment failure. You and Hal could have checked it from then till now and it still would have happened. (beat) You did everything right -- GABE -- If I did everything right, Susan Collins would still be alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: whizzes on to the Ranger station -- a small building by an old country road. Not much activity outside of some ROOKIE CLIMBERS working out on a CLIMBING PRACTICE WALL. Maggie starts to land the copter, and as she does -- INSIDE THE COPTER GABE Do you really believe all that?  That it wasn't our fault? Maggie slows the rotor, her eyes on the controls. Gabe's eyes are locked on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But she answered a half beat too slow. The helicopter touches ground.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (turns to Gabe) Yes. Yes, I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure what I wish more, Maggie. That you meant what you said, just now
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: or that it were really true then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hal, wearing Sheriff's garb, storms towards Maggie's side of the copter as the engine shuts off and the rotor dies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe gets out of the copter, and Hal sees him for the first time. Unlike the last time we saw them, neither man is glad to see the other. Hal turns on Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie takes off as Gabe and Hal step away from the copter. Gabe eyes Hal's uniform and almost -- not quite but almost -- laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rookie climbers get off the practice wall to watch this faceoff. Gabe and Hal are one crack away from beating hell out of each other. Frank heads over to defuse the confrontation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That tears it -- Hal rushes Gabe and they pummel each other until Frank and the others pull them apart, panting and bleeding.  Hal throws off the men holding him back -- but instead of going at Gabe again, Hal throws Gabe a set of car keys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hal heads back into the office -- Gabe heads for the Bronco.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Maggie, where the hell have you been? I've got two climbers out --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brett and Evan are up there again to jump off the spur. Their wives called twice. I want you in the air and I want them found before the storm system moves in. (Maggie hesitates) Now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Christ. You're in charge of Rescue now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There was a vacancy. Maybe you heard about it. The last guy lost his nerve and lit out of town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you're a better man than I am, Hal. Nothing rattles you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (steering Gabe away) Gabe! Long time, son -- why don't you come meet some of the new guys -- GABE Good idea. Say, Hal? (beat) Why don't you come with me so we can show these rookies how to death-rig a woman properly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take the Bronco to where you're going. I've already been. Then go back to wherever it is you like to hide. And stay there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Southwest regional center for printing and distributing currency. Hundreds of troops stand guard over the impressive U.S. Treasury complex.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is at work -- the ROAR of its parts is deafening as it stamps out a plate design on huge sheets of paper -- we move in on
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: which is moved by mechanical arm to a SLICER that razors the bills apart -- it's moving too fast for us to see the denomination -- the cut bills are separated by -- FOUR SEPARATION CHUTES that fire the bills down to a mechanical COUNTER that serializes, counts, bands and stacks them faster than any human could -- a HAND reaches to pick up a band -- THE BILLS are something a banker could work a lifetime without seeing, but are real nonetheless --  $5,000 bills, banded here in hundreds. The band is put back in the growing stack by
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: mid-thirties, a tough, imposing Treasury agent -- he regards the fortune piling up in front of him with only cold, professional interest. Travers is flanked by a trio of equally tough TREASURY AGENTS -- he turns to flunky DAVIS (20s). It's clear who's in charge of protecting the money here, and who's in charge of counting it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Davis dials we move to -- THE OFFICE of WALTER WRIGHT (50s), comptroller of currency -- his demeanor suggests he's in control, and used to keeping it that way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Wright gets up from his desk, though, we hear in the outer office -- SECRETARY (O.S.) You can't go in there -- MATHESON (O.S.) Watch me.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tell Wright the San Francisco shipment is ready.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (phone already out) Right away, Mr. Travers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Good -- good. I'll be right down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (30s) bursts into the office, trailed by Wright's flustered SECRETARY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Walter Wright? (flashes badge) Matheson. FBI. We need to talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE MONEY has now been packed into a trio of metal briefcases -- ten thousand $5,000 bills. Travers shuts the cases in turn, and locks each with an electronic key card, triggering a FLASHING RED LIGHT on the locks as he does. A uniformed PILOT shows up behind Travers as he cuffs the cases to the hands of the three other agents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers looks up at Matheson, who has just arrived with Wright. Travers is instantly furious at the challenge to his authority.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Matheson draws out a file and hands it to Travers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Matheson hands Travers a folder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We look over Travers' shoulder at the photos, which are all blurry, all blown up from different surveillance pictures -- and all of them show ERIC QUALEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Matheson still isn't convinced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers pulls a tracking device about the size of a watchman out of his jacket pocket. The small screen shows three red blips at rest -- matching the three currency cases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers, angry, turns to Wright. Wright clearly doesn't like this either, but is resigned to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers turns back to a smiling Matheson, looking like he'd rather kill him instead, as we -- CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We'll be fueled and ready in ten minutes, Mr. Travers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (an order) Be ready in five.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Go ahead and take ten. We'll need the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flashes badge) Matheson. FBI.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking down at it) Your parents must be proud. (to Wright) What the fuck is this about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Small problem with the shipment, Travers. (to Matheson) Tell him what you just told me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got word that somebody's been observing your currency shipments -- this load, the $5,000s -- over the last three deliveries.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) There isn't a hell of a lot anyone can do but observe. (beat) This is the most protected shipment we've got -- and the most useless for a thief. Those bills aren't in circulation. You think five thousand dollar bills are easy to pass? Who the fuck would try?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This guy might.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (patient) His name's Eric Qualen. One of the East German spies who got shut out by the reunification. The CIA issued an inter-agency warning about him right after the wall came down. He's got nowhere to go and nothing to lose. He's also got the international connections to get rid of bills like these -- and he's probably desperate enough to try for them. Fifty million bucks buys a lot of sanctuary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could you get to the part where I'm supposed to care?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shows him more photos) We had two agents monitoring him. These two -- Gleason and Quinones. Their last report said he was going to try to take this shipment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning away) Thanks for the tip. But I've got work to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stopping him) Did I say "last" report? I think I did. I mean last fucking report. These guys have vanished.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have my sympathy, but -- (exasperated) There's a reason we do things this way, all right? Armored cars can be hijacked. Trains can be derailed. But nobody can get to us in flight. The only time this is on the ground is at the mint, or on the Presidio runway in San Francisco. Either way, someone would have to shoot his way past a couple of thousand guards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're worried about an inside job, forget it. I checked the plane from top to bottom an hour ago. And these three are my best against. Even if one of them did go skydiving, they wouldn't get far. Each case has an electronic tracer with a range of one hundred miles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (facing down Matheson) I haven't lost a bill in eight years. And I'm not scrubbing this shipment because you scare easily.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (an easy smile) Who said anything about stopping the shipment? (beat) I've been tracking Qualen for almost a year. If he pulls something, I want to be in on the party.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is cleared from the top, Travers. Matheson will accompany you on the flight to San Francisco. (beat) Show him every professional courtesy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is being buffeted by storm winds and a light snow -- Maggie struggles hard with the controls, but -- INSIDE HELICOPTER Visibility is near zero. Maggie keys the radio.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rescue One to base, over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Rescue One -- have you sighted them? Over -- MAGGIE Negative, Hal -- storm's already moving in -- I can't see them, and winds are too strong to stay up here -- over -- HAL (O.S.) Rescue One -- abort. They'll be all right. Brett and Evan are dumb enough not to log in, but they're smart enough to have storm gear. Head back to base. (not unkindly) Maybe you can catch Gabe before he leaves. Over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think he's planning a long visit, Hal. (back to business) Rescue One heading back to base, over and out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: banks a 180 to fly back -- we can see over the horizon that the storm is moving in fast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can hear Maggie's helicopter flying off overhead -- camped inside the cave are BRETT and EVAN, both 20s, both shivering, amid their gear -- backpacks, cooking stuff -- and parachutes. These are Colorado rock jocks -- thrillseekers who'll try anything if the odds are strong enough they'll die in the process.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (freezing) Way to check the weather, Brett.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shivering yet macho) Hey. If it were easy, it wouldn't be worth d-doing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The DC-9 cruises over increasingly mountainous, remote terrain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: who looks tense -- we MOVE AROUND the cabin and find two more relaxed Treasury agents are dozing on the opposite side of the plane, their arms chained to the currency cases. Matheson is edgy. Another AGENT offers some condescending reassurance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Matheson turns back to his window and looks down -- WINDOW POV - THE GROUND BELOW is covered with snow -- the jet's shadow moves sleekly and plainly over it. But after a moment we see -- -- another jet's shadow on the ground, coming up fast!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Just enjoy the view, huh? (Matheson says nothing) Relax. I mean, what could happen in the air?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - MATHESON reacts this and shifts his look upward to -- WINDOW POV - ANOTHER PLANE (GULFSTREAM) is flying a parallel course to the Treasury jet, and is just one hundred yards away. Close enough to see Eric Qualen's face in one of the windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Matheson stands -- Travers has noticed the plane by now too, and gets out of his seat as the other agents react.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers moves into
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to other agents) Stay put! Don't panic, goddammit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: where the pilot seems nervous, but oddly, not frightened.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He's coming in too slow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cool) No -- we're going too fast, and we're too high up. Push flaps forward twenty degrees and drop to five thousand feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Matheson is out of his seat, pistol drawn. Seems a little puny under the circumstances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Matheson rushes through a curtain to the area between the cabin and the cockpit and pulls open a closet door. To his horror, he finds inside not rifles, but
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to agent) You got any rifles?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forward compartment -- left side --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: who we'll recognize as the missing FBI agents from the photos Matheson showed Travers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: backs up in horror -- and he sees Travers calmly coming out of the cockpit. Rattled, Matheson pulls his gun on Travers. Travers looks dumbfounded -- then angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers puts his hands out and walks forward -- slowly, backing Matheson into the cabin. Not in surrender, but as if he's calming a nutcase. The other agents see this and don't know which way to jump.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They now think Matheson is crazy too -- he looks nuts -- the other agents move behind him. Matheson gets even more frantic and point his gun at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other two agents get behind Matheson and rapidly disarm him. Travers pulls out his gun with a slow, leisurely move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers FIRES his gun three times, one for each agent's chest -- the agents are cut down, realizing too late what's happened. A fourth SHOT knocks Matheson over a seat as if he'd been kicked. Travers puts his gun away and puts on a radio headset as he goes to a window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell are you doing -- MATHESON Checked the plane from top to bottom, huh? You fucker -- (clicks hammer back) Put your hands behind your head! It's over!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Calm down -- give the gun to me -- MATHESON (to other agents) There's a couple of dead bodies in the front compartment -- they're FBI agents -- TRAVERS He's losing it --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn it! Don't you see what he's doing! He's hijacking the fucking shipment! (back to Travers) Don't make me shoot you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't make me laugh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to mouthpiece) Move into position.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: maneuvers over the DC-9 -- and holds steady above it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stone reads "Susan Collins -- 1965 - 1991". It's surrounded by wreaths -- one of which has an old snapshot of her attached to it. Mementos sent on the first anniversary of her death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: brushes some of the falling snow away from the marker. He lays down his flowers and pauses for a moment -- then gets into the Bronco and drives away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe looks out the window at the countryside he used to belong in. He's wondering if he still does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Qualen's jet is now flying parallel to, and slightly above, the Treasury jet. The door in Qualen's jet is open, and we get our first good look at -- INT/EXT. QUALEN'S JET -- Qualen, who is also wearing a headset radio and is wired to a safety line in the jet. He's lowering a thick steel cable down to the Treasury jet. Qualen is as deadly as advertised -- 150 mph winds are tearing at him through the open door, but he is unfazed and unfrightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is also wired to a safety line by his own jet's open door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE TWO PLANES Qualen's jet lowers the cable into the Treasury jet -- it looks like an Air Force midair refuelling -- difficult and dangerous. After about thirty feet of line is lowered -- TRAVERS -- takes it in and clips it to a ring at the top of the jet's doorway.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into radio) More -- more -- keep it coming --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into radio) Locked on. Move into lateral position.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The pilot, KRISTEL, is a woman. Her skill, like her hard beauty, can be measured in a glance: she's a lot calmer than her counterpart in the Treasury plane.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Moving into lateral position.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Qualen's jet lowers itself, banking to the side -- the Treasury jet raises itself. Both are now flying side by side, with the cable serving as a thirty foot bridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers, unclipped from his safety line, cautiously goes to the cockpit. The pilot, nervous, struggles with the controls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers pulls the two dead FBI agents out of the compartment -- one is dressed in a flying suit like the pilot, one in a suit like Travers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers opens one of the cases, which is identical to the others -- except that it's full of one dollar bills. He's thought of everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers moves back into the cabin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We're right on the edge of the storm -- let's move it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This isn't going to work -- Wright will suspect something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what. He'll sift though a plane that went down in a storm -- (gestures to bodies)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: find enough pulverized bone for six men heroically killed in the line of duty -- (finds three suitcases)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: and just enough of the right kind of ash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We get twenty-one gun funerals and they write off fifty million. It's perfect, as long as you hold the plane steady -- so concentrate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We can now see four other passengers. All are fit and armed -- HELDON and RYAN are seated, while KYNETTE and DELMER, ready to help with the transfer, are on the opposite side of the door from a very impatient Qualen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into radio) Travers -- hurry it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Travers, now in a harness like the one seen earlier -- uncuffs the money cases from the agents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers steps back into the cockpit and flips a toggle switch over and LED -- THE LED starts counting down from 2:00 -- 1:59 -- 1:58 -- IN THE COCKPIT Even in the last minute, the storm's gotten worse -- the plane is flying right into the blackest center of it. The pilot looks more panicked than ever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers heads back into the cabin and hooks his harness to the cable between the planes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into radio) On my way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That charge is going to blow both engines -- the plane'll go down like a rock, so clip yourself on to the end of the cable with the money as soon as I get over. (an afterthought) And make sure you bring the right cases.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into the headset) Dip the plane. I'm coming over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - LONG SHOT Qualen's jet dips down so there's a sharp incline -- Travers starts the slide down, zipping in seconds across into
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: where he's pulled in and unclipped by Qualen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Qualen smiles in reply. No. Maybe he wouldn't.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting over the wind) Why didn't you send the money over?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting too) Somehow, I didn't think you'd have waited for me if I'd sent it first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The pilot locks the controls and rushes back to the cabin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: counts down -- 0:38 -- 0:37 -- 0:38 -- IN THE TREASURY PLANE CABIN The pilot gathers the cases and uses their cuffs to attach them to the cable -- but as he steps past the bodies of -- THE AGENTS Matheson's eyes open -- he's not dead yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pilot clicks the last of the three cases onto the cable and is about to put his harness on -- but behind him, Matheson shakily crawls to his feet, draws his gun, and SHOOTS the pilot in the back twice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: drops out of the plane, flailing -- if he's screaming, we can't hear it over the HOWLING of the storm -- IN QUALEN'S JET Qualen and Travers are watching the whole plan unravel -- TRAVERS (shouting to cockpit) Get underneath the jet! The cases will slide over!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - LONG SHOT Qualen's jet sharply dips down and the cases start to slide over -- but at the same time -- INSIDE THE TREASURY JET Matheson, groggy, holds onto the doorway and FIRES a full clip from his automatic at Qualen's jet -- and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are destroyed as the charge DETONATES -- THE JETS - LONG SHOT As promised, the Treasury jet is now plummetting as if it had no wings at all, levelling the angle between the planes -- the cases dangle precariously on the wire -- INSIDE QUALEN'S JET TRAVERS (shouting) Lower! Get underneath it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Matheson struggles to the cockpit and gets behind the controls
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as if that's going to do any good -- THE JETS - LONG SHOT Qualen's jet is deliberately racing the disabled Treasury jet down, but it's hopeless -- there's no way to get underneath the falling jet long enough for the cases to slide over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - KRISTEL isn't quite panicked. Yet.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's dragging us down! Disconnect the cable!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Heldon and Ryan try to do just that, but the cable is taut -- there's no way to loosen the clip on the door -- BOTH JETS dive down faster at an ever steeper angle, over the edge of the Colorado mountain range -- INSIDE THE TREASURY JET -- the clip on the door finally breaks -- BOTH JETS - LONG SHOT -- the Treasury jet drops as Qualen's jet, trailing the cable and the money, sharply shoots upward -- THE TREASURY JET makes a one point landing nose first into the wilderness, cartwheeling into a FIREBALL!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sound of the EXPLOSION, muffled in the wind, far-off, but audible, drives Hal outside -- he's alert, but can't see anything in the murk of the storm -- INT. QUALEN'S JET - THE COCKPIT - KRISTEL levels off the plane, but it's still in trouble -- CABIN - QUALEN AND TRAVERS struggle to reel in the cable, because -- CLOSE ON THE CABLE The money cases are still, barely, holding on, the cuffs caught on the broken clip at the end -- QUALEN AND TRAVERS aren't even bothering with the electric winch, they're dragging it in hand over hand -- but -- CLOSE ON THE CABLE -- the cases, torn by the wind, work their way loose one at a time and drop -- one -- two -- three -- into the snowy mountains below!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heldon and Ryan clamp the door shut as Qualen angrily attacks Travers -- THE COCKPIT - KRISTEL tries to bring the plane up, but can't -- the fuel guage needle is dropping fast -- INSERT - THE WING is pouring out fuel through a dozen bullet holes -- one of two engines sputters to a stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - KRISTEL POV The plane is now just skirting the mountain tops, and is still being battered by storm winds -- Kristel aims it for what looks like the flattest, longest mountain top -- THE CABIN Kynette and Ryan grab Qualen and Travers to separate them -- all strap in, because
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is going down -- it just tops the edge of a precipice and hits the ground level -- THE MOUNTAIN TOP - LONG SHOT -- the problem is, the ground itself isn't level, it tilts down towards another edge five hundred yards distant -- if the plane keeps skidding, it'll go over the edge -- THE PLANE sleds down at an angle, skipping over rocks -- -- through trees -- -- tearing off a wing -- THE COCKPIT Kristel rides the stick only out of habit -- nothing she does is going to matter now -- INSIDE THE CABIN The men are jolted around -- windows IMPLODE as Kynette tries to protect a bag of what is obviously explosives -- THE PLANE rips downhill through a wooded area like a runaway train -- -- the second wing is sheared off by trees -- COCKPIT POV - THE OPPOSITE EDGE is coming up fast -- but
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wrenches to a sudden halt, the fuselage intact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R VIEW - THE PLANE or what's left of it has stopped several feet short of the edge -- we can see why: the steel cable, trailing from the cargo door, has lashed itself around a half dozen trees, acting as a tripwire to stop the plane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quiet. All are dazed but, outside of superficial cuts, unhurt. Kristel moves out of the cockpit, looking around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She speaks for all of them -- especially a still-seething Qualen. Travers pulls out the tracer monitor for the cases. The tracer screen shows three distinct blips -- the tracers have survived the fall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So much for phase one. (to Travers) Now what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now -- we call the police.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hal, agitated, paces in the main office -- Frank, unconcerned, puts a coat hanger and some aluminum foil on a little TV to drag in the fading signal of a Broncos game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The station's scanner radio barks to life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hal runs to the radio and keys the mike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: INT. COCKPIT Kristel is on the radio, as Travers and Qualen hang back. Kristel's voice is panicked but she can't suppress a grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: INT. RANGER STATION HAL Acknowledged, mayday. What's your position?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dead silence. The transmission cuts off/
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: INT. COCKPIT Kristel hangs up the radio and smiles, Travers and Qualen standing behind her. Qualen lightly applauds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: EXT. COUNTRY ROAD - DAY The Bronco wends through a winding country road, coming finally to a cabin settled in a clearing. GABE pulls into the driveway and puts the Bronco in park. He doesn't cut the engine, because he's not sure whether he's going in or not. Finally -- he cuts the ignition. INT. CABIN - DAY A knock on the door brings no response -- no one inside. Gabe opens the unlocked door -- and steps inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No answer. Gabe takes a look around the living room. His face tells us, without a doubt, this used to be his home. Gabe moves inside, pausing at a mantle. Two framed photos -- Gabe and Maggie sleeping together in a hammock, bolted to a sheer wall over a 2,000 foot drop. Gabe, Hal and Maggie, all younger, all sporting drunken grins, in a mountain cave.  Gabe smiles for the first time today at this memory -- a BANGING at the back of the cabin shakes him out of it. EXT. CABIN - DAY - THE BACK DOOR has come open and swings in the wind. Gabe steps outside and pulls it shut. Gabe looks down and sees tracks that lead to a small but sturdy shed a few yards away. Gabe heads over to it. INT. SHED - DAY Not a storage shed at all -- it's a small workspace that offers solid protection from the elements, is well-lit, and whistle-clean. Maggie, in front of a table, pulls a cover off. A LARGE PLASTIC CAGE -- inside is a bald eagle. One of maybe 2,000 left in the country. Its uneven feathering and small, gawky size tells us it isn't nearly full grown. A bandage on its side tells us it's been injured. Maggie's smile tells us it's healing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door to the shed opens -- Gabe steps in, and shuts the door behind him. Maggie looks surprised to see him. Gabe just looks awkward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie pulls on a pair of pair of cowhide gloves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie reaches into the cage, but the eagle starts thrashing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe finds another pair of gloves, sterile cotton pads and alcohol in a drawer -- Maggie reaches in and grabs the eagle's beak and talons quickly but gently, and takes it out of the cage, holding it firm. This is clearly something they've done many times before. They move together, tight -- Gabe and Maggie both react to this bit of close contact as they bandage the eagle. It's getting warmer in here. Gabe reaches down and yanks off the patch. The eagle thrashes as Gabe cleans the wound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe winces at this one as he carefully tapes the small patch and sticks it on the eagle's side. Maggie puts the eagle back in the cage and closes the top door. Gabe and Maggie don't move any further apart as they pull their gloves off. Gabe tentatively reaches for Maggie's face -- but she pushes him hand away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Standing in the shed's doorway is Hal. Stone faced. Grim. OUTSIDE SHED Furious, Gabe heads out after Hal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe walks past Hal. Furious, Hal spins Gabe around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe knows he's right. But he's hesitant. And scared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe turns. Sees Maggie in the doorway. She's heard every word. Gabe turns to Hal -- hesitates -- and nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look -- I know there's a storm, but that wasn't thunder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (unconcerned) Hal, when you've been in this line as long as I have --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (panicky) Mayday -- mayday -- downed DC-3 -- mayday --

dialogue.raw_text: dead, seven seriously wounded, acknowledge --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) ("panicked") Don't know -- position unknown -- landed on top of some mountain -- only visual bearing is a facing cylinder-type formation -- over -- HAL Got to be Comb Bluff. (keys mike) Acknowledged, mayday. Winds are too strong for us to get a copter up there
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: can you and your passengers make it through the storm? Over -- KRISTEL (O.S. Negative -- cockpit is on fire -- fuselage broken into three sep-- ("garble") --ed in shock.  Need medical supplies, including insulin, repeat, insulin, as soon as po --

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not bad. The insulin was a nice touch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maggie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey there --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi. (beat) Could you introduce us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. Gabe Walker -- this is A27.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gabe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not the tag -- what do you call him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Her. I call her Lucky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bends down, eyes wound) Poachers? (Maggie nods) Bastards...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They got the mother -- and left this one behind. Too small to make a decent trophy, I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About four months, right? (Maggie nods) Christ -- it must have been just about his -- I mean her -- first flight -- MAGGIE Time to change the dressing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't do that alone -- MAGGIE I've had to learn. She trust me --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm making her nervous -- (beat) You hold her, I'll do the dressing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got some fight in her -- that's good. (beat) What happened to Dave?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The usual. Flew off -- never calls, never writes --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad to see you, Gabe. But I kind of wish you hadn't come. I was almost used to you being gone. (beat, quiet) Why are you here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pauses) I thought I came back to see if I'd learned to live with it. Well, big surprise. Coming back just tore me open all over again, like it all happened yesterday instead of a year ago. Nothing's changed. Including the way I feel about you. (beat) I didn't realize it till I saw you at the airport. But I came back for you, Maggie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does that mean you're going to stay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Not here. (beat) I want you come with me. Start over, somewhere else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) You come back after being gone a year, and you expect me to -- (beat) You don't live here any more, Gabe. Your choice, remember? But this is my home. I'm not leaving. You can stay with me, or you can go alone. It's still your choice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Now there's an easy call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) I need your help. A plane's gone down on Comb Bluff. This storm would blow a copter all over the place -- but we can climb up to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "We"? (beat) Talk to somebody who's still on the payroll. You've got a half dozen new guys -- HAL -- who couldn't climb that wall now if there were stairs cut into it. But you've soloed it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: During the summer. On a bet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is a little more important than a bet. Just a few injured people with no first aid or shelter, camping in a zero degree blizzard. They'll be ice sculptures by tomorrow morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes his head) Maybe you missed the headlines -- but I don't do rescues any more. They're bad for my conscience. (beat) Fuck this one up on your own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Play it again, Gabe, about how we killed her. I was there too, remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hot) Not like I was, pal -- her fingers brushed mine on the way down -- HAL (right back)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: and I was the one who had to deal with her family when you fucking tore out of town. (takes a breath) We lost her. Whatever anybody says about cold stress and the clip, you and I have to live with that. But right now, there are some more people who need our help, and they shouldn't die too just because you've got a problem keeping the past in the past.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want the responsibility.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Walk away and you are responsible. They'll die. I can't do this alone. (Gabe slows but doesn't stop) You know what else, Gabe? You can go anywhere you want, but if you don't do this, now, you're going to be stuck on that goddamn ledge for the rest of your life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Relative to the other mountains, Comb Bluff is smaller -- about 2,500 feet high. But that's like saying the Empire State Building is smaller than the Sears Tower. It's still a long way up if you're climbing the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - GABE AND HAL with full packs of mountaineering gear on. They've got to climb up this beast. Gabe -- now back in his orange Sheriff's jacket -- scrambles with Hal up the base of the mountain, the last few yards before it turns into a sloping wall. Gabe takes a bolt gun -- which fires rope-fastened bolts into rock -- and hangs it from a strap on his chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe readies a coil of rope and starts up the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hal starts up after Gabe, easily keeping pace with him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating gun) That thing's dead weight. Completely useless for an ice climb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just backup.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not a challenge) I'll lead. I left a few bolts last time I climbed this -- I think I can find some of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Save the rope for when it gets tough. (beat, realizing) That bet was for you to free climb the wall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (further up) Tell you what, Hal -- if we're still alive tomorrow morning, I'll give you the twenty bucks back, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - LONG SHOT Two orange specks move their way up the mountain -- it's definitely going to be a long trip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DAY - GABE AND HAL are now visibly two-thirds of the way up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ON GABE AND HAL - THE MOUNTAIN FACE is not only higher, it's a lot tougher to climb. Instead of being angular, the wall is now completely vertical -- and coated with ice. Rough, irregular ice ledges are all Gabe and Hal can grip -- it's a matter of grabbing what you can for a handhold, and kicking the spikes of the steel crampons on their boots into the ice for footholds. Gabe leads, planting pitons into the ice, threading the rope through them as he goes. Three steel pins between Gabe and Hal. Their only safety net. Gabe, trailing rope behind him, goes up a difficult slab of ice and climbs under a ledge, where he anchors the rope in the ice with another piton.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting down) Anchored!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is beside and slightly below Gabe -- at the other end of the fifty foot rope. Hal cautiously pulls himself along the line to the first piton -- as is standard for a climb, he pulls out the piton, then moves on to the second -- but up above
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ice, building in a small crevase, builds and CRACKS the adjoining rock -- several ten-pound boulders fall, causing a chain reaction
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: that bounces down the wall -- GABE hugs the ice wall, making himself as flat as possible -- GABE (shouting down) Rockslide!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: flattens too as rocks bounce past -- the second anchoring piton LOOSENS as it is struck by a falling rock -- Hal nervously eyes the last piton between him and Gabe -- THE PITON - CLOSE also has been clipped by the still falling boulders and droops at half mast -- no way are these going to hold in the unreliable ice -- HAL tries to stay flat, but one boulder painfully CLIPS him on the shoulder, knocking him from his perch -- Hal falls -- WIDER - HAL FALLING In falling, Hal's weight on the rope yanks out the nearest anchor piton -- Hal tumbles in space, keeping pace with the boulders, as -- GABE who's seen everything we have, quickly reaches to the piton he's just anchored, and removes the carabiner clip -- HAL - FALLING The rope draws taut, yanking out the last piton between he and Gabe -- nothing but a few yards of slack rope now -- GABE has the bolt gun out. He rapidly hooks the rope's carabiner clip to the chambered bolt, and FIRES it at a solid rock ledge above him -- INSERT - THE BOLT imbeds solidly in the rock -- GABE lashes the rope to his shoulder, bracing for the coming impact by lodging his feet in the ice -- THE JOLT - WIDER SHOT The line pulls taut, leaving Hal suspended, the wind knocked out of him from the impact -- GABE is almost dragged down by the jolt -- he painfully takes most of the impact in his shoulders -- the shock forces his feet through an ice ledge -- but the rope, bolted to the rock above, has held. Barely.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shaken, voice gone) Anchored -- (shouts this time) Anchored!

direction.raw_text: now somewhat recovered, steadies himself.

direction.raw_text: Gabe heads up and over
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on -- the hard part's over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and helps Hal up. From here, the rest of the range looms large. Even in the continuing snowstorm, it's a spectacular sight -- but Gabe and Hal don't pause to enjoy it. This isn't a trip for sport. Hal looks off into the trees, and sees the torn tree stumps from the plane crash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hal and Gabe run into the wooded area and follow the wreckage -- felled trees, a smashed wing -- and reach
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (grim) That's it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: which sits intact by the other edge of the precipice.

direction.raw_text: Hal pulls open the passenger door and goes in -- Gabe, wary, takes a look around the plane.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I thought the fuselage was broken. That looks pretty cozy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled too) The pilot was hysterical.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something's wrong here -- HAL Does this look like a prank to you? Come on --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's comparatively dark in here -- Hal starts in, shining a light -- the beam finds
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: slumped down on the cabin floor, a blanket wrapped around him -- he's shaking and is generally giving a good impression of a shock victim. Hal rushes to him.

direction.raw_text: "Weak", Travers whispers as Hal gives him some water.

direction.raw_text: Travers won't quit -- Hal leans down to hear.

direction.raw_text: A gun barrel moves INTO VIEW as it presses against Hal's neck. Heldon and Ryan are right behind him. Travers instantly drops his act.

dialogue.raw_text: Relax -- we're here to help --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't try to talk --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hoarse whisper) Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where? What are you --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You said "we". Where are the rest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - OUTSIDE THE FUSELAGE notes footprints in the snow -- fresh ones -- and kneels down to look at the cable wrapped around the tree. No ordinary accident. But before he can think about this, he gets an earful of gun barrel from Qualen, who is behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Qualen hustles Gabe inside the plane -- his hands are on his head, and his pack has been removed. Qualen throws the pack to Ryan and Delmer, who rifle through it, removing anything that could be a weapon -- they quickly confiscate Gabe's bolt gun and ice axe.

direction.raw_text: Travis looks at Hal's park ranger badge.

direction.raw_text: Qualen tosses it to Travers, who glances through it.

direction.raw_text: Travers motions to Ryan and Qualen, who shove Gabe and Hal forward in the cabin. Travers takes out the tracer monitor.

direction.raw_text: Gabe and Hal eye each other -- no choice. Gabe nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's for dinner? (Kynette tosses packet) Ugh. "Dried Beef Slices With Barbeque Sauce." (tosses it back) Try and make this edible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hal Tucker. (to Gabe) Where's yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He doesn't have one. Just a wallet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gabe Walker... (notes photo of Maggie) Very attractive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My ex.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too bad. Let me tell you what's on for today. We'd like you to help settle a wager. You see, we lost some luggage --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (showing them the blips) See these? Now I've bet the gentlemen behind you that you know enough about this mountain range to lead us to each of these, quickly, and that you'd be happy to do so. They bet me you couldn't and wouldn't. (guns are clicked) Now tell me -- who wins?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good dog. Now let's get this expedition started.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hal and Gabe lead the "expedition" down a steep, but passable, descent, leading to -- A NATURAL STONE BRIDGE that links Comb Bluff with the next mountain. Travers stops Gabe and pulls out the monitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe pauses as he holds the monitor up against the mountainscape.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Connect the dots.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The first blip is up a thousand feet -- it's a wall, and obviously not something for a novice. Gabe pauses a little too long -- Qualen nudges him with his gun. Gabe hands the monitor back to Travers.

direction.raw_text: Gabe, with Hal right behind, leads them up the wall -- it's not a straight climb, but there's a series of zig-zagging natural ledges that cut up the wall. Wide enough even for an amateur. The others follow Gabe and Hal's example.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - DAY - HAL AND GABE have led the gang further up the wall, using pitons and carabiner clips to create a guide rope. It's still just a matter of climbing relatively easy ascending ledges. Hal and Gabe lead them by jumping to the next ledge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ON HAL AND GABE As Gabe hammers in a new piton, he turns to Hal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe nods grimly -- and keeps moving up. The rest keep pace.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto) We don't have to do this. We know these mountains -- they don't. If we can get ahead -- HAL Can you climb faster than they can shoot?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've got to try something. Think we'll get a finder's fee after they get all their "luggage"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. All the bullets we can eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not what really worries me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's something else to worry about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Once they've got what they're after -- they're gonna need a copter to get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (realizing) Maggie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The climbers have reached a point of comparative comfort on the wall -- the ledge is now two feet wide. Travers takes out the tracer monitor -- the monitor shows that the first case is just above them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hold it. (beat) It's up there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - AN OVERHANG juts out of the wall fifty feet above their position. As the rest of the wall above is completely sheer, it's obvious that the case, if it is above, has landed on top of a ledge. But this isn't easily accessible -- we MOVE DOWN from the overhang and can see there are only the smallest of handholds to get up there, and those are slick with ice and snow. Worse, the rest of the mountain bulges outward in a curve, making climbing almost impossible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers holds his gun on Gabe, and motions up
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers nods -- Kynette pulls a roll of tape out of Gabe's confiscated pack and throws it to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crampons too. Travers hesitates, but nods -- Kynette throws him the iron spikes. Gabe fastens them to his boots. Gabe looks up -- this is going to be tough, even for him. In spite of the cold, he takes off his gloves -- that's how small these holds are -- and he meticulously tapes up his hands and his fingers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Fetch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll need the ice axe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) You've got to be kidding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs) Okay. How about some tape?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: moves up the wall with some ease at first -- there are hand-sized handholds, and decent footholds -- but twenty feet up, there's nothing. To keep going, Gabe has to painfully wedge his fingers into small cracks, essentially supporting his weight only by several fingerholds at any given moment. We can see from the angle that Gabe is at least 3,000 feet from solid ground. We can see from his face that he's trying not to think about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - TRAVERS AND QUALEN watch Gabe's slow progress.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't trust him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating wall) Where could he go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd rather he didn't show us. (beat) We don't need two guides.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) You win. Kill him when he gets down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Make that "if he comes down". Gabe is now in one of the worst positions possible for a free climb. He is moving up the underside of the overhang and is essentially hanging upside down, knifing his fingers into tiny cracks for support. It's excruciating -- both in terms of muscular effort, and the abrasions that come from forcing fingers into ice and rock again and again. Gabe keeps his hold with one hand and slides the other up, hammering it into a crack wedge with ice -- some of the ice chips whistle past and down -- -- finally, Gabe gropes one hand over the edge, and pulls himself onto
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exhausted, Gabe pulls himself prone across the top. Something hard is underneath him -- Gabe recovers and brushes the snow off the money case that's underneath. It's battered from the fall, but is still barely holding together. Gabe manages to force open the trashed locks -- he looks inside the case, and fingers a band of $5000s.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - TRAVERS AND QUALEN look up. They can see Gabe has made it -- but they can't see him, or the case.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (impatient, shouting) Lower it down -- now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - GAB has no intention of doing this -- he snaps the case shut and looks over at a ledge that moves off from it -- and at the ice and snow above.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - TRAVERS AND QUALEN'S POV try to look up and locate Gabe. They can't. Until -- GABE (O.S.) (shouting down) I've got a better idea. Why don't you come up and get it? With the case, Gabe moves, back against the wall, on a ledge that skirts off the overhand -- from Travers and Qualen's point of view. Gabe can hardly be seen -- since the mountain bulges out as it goes up. Gabe's got a slight edge of cover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heldon runs along the lower ledge, FIRING up at -- GABE who has to flatten against the upper ledge -- bullets howl past at twenty per second, SPARKING against the lip of the rock -- it's cover, but not much -- HAL looks up, worried -- HAL'S POV - ICE AND SNOW piled by the ton from the storm, lie further above -- the ice holding it back already, already weakened by the sun, is being chiselled away by bullets -- ON THE LOWER LEDGE - QUALEN grabs Hal and puts the gun to his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers pushes the barrel away from Hal, shaking his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shouts to Heldon) Get him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting) Bring the money down, or we kill your friend!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can't. (frowning) And he knows it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE ON MOUNTAIN - THE PARALLEL LEDGES Gabe moves across his thing ledge as Heldon runs across his -- Gabe ducks back and has to flatten even more against the wall, because his ledge is getting smaller -- HELDON smiles, seeing Gabe's cover is gone -- Heldon's ledge is getting wider, so it's easier for him to fire up. Heldon moves out to the edge -- GABE'S POV DOWN There's now nothing between Heldon and Gabe -- Heldon takes dead aim -- GABE looks up, sweating it -- GABE Come on -- THE ICE AND SNOW above finally give way, dropping an avalanche on
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: who drops the case and hugs the wall -- THE AVALANCHE - WIDE VIEW ON MOUNTAIN Only now can we see how much snow and ice had been penned up on the mountain top -- tons of ice and snow sweep down the mountainside -- it SHATTERS the case against the wall as it easily swipes a SCREAMING Heldon off the ledge -- TRAVERS, QUALEN AND HAL are safe at their vantage, but stunned at the sight of -- THE AVALANCHE Heldon's machine fun FIRES uselessly as he's swallowed in an explosion of white -- as well as a flurry of green as the bills scatter amid the snow -- -- then: quiet. The avalanche ends as abruptly as it started. The rumble dies down to complete silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: apoplectic, stares at seventeen million dollars worth of snow settling far below. He takes his gun, furious, and fires at
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: where Gabe was hugging the wall -- it's now blanketed with snow. Travers FIRES an entire clip at where Gabe used to be. The snow FALLS AWAY, revealing nothing but stark rock. Gabe has been swept away.

direction.raw_text: reacts and attacks Travers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers turns and pins Hal against the wall with the gun, ready to kill him too. But he's stopped by Qualen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Travers, furious, takes the gun out of Hal's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hal stares at Travers with absolute fury -- but he leads the gang back along the ledge in retreat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You son of a bitch --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. We need him to get the rest of the money. (he isn't backing down) If he dies we lose everything
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Hal) Get us out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue
